titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxiv — no.40 Richmond, Va. Monday, February 2, 1863. price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at Six and A Quarter cents per week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: The army of the Potomac.
div3.p:
We learn from the best authority that a scout in the Signal service, just from Maryland, reports, from personal observation, that the whole Yankee army is leaving Aquia Creek, the greater portion bound to Washington and the remainder to Old Point.
The published object of this move is to "recruit and reorganize." Furloughs were being issued in great profusion to quiet the discontent in the Yankee army.

div3.head: The French proposition to the U. S. Government.
div3.p:
By the arrival of the steamship Europe at Halifax, we have Liverpool dates to the 25th ult. The rumors of foreign intervention begin to thicken, and wear an air of probability.
The Paris correspondent of the London Times has reason to know that the French Government has officially instructed M. Mercier to advise the Government at Washington to appoint commissioners to meet on neutral ground a similar delegation from the Confederate States, for the purpose of endeavoring to effect a reconciliation by mutual concession.
The Paris Pays confirms the above statement.
The Le Nord, at Brussels, also states positively that France has proposed the convocation of an American Congress--or Convention, probably — with a view to peace.
The London Times sees no hope of arriving at any satisfactory adjustment between the belligerents, by any voluntary act of the belligerents themselves, but intimates that the demand for a ssation of hostilities will come "from some quarter of which present circumstances afford indications"

div3.head: Election of a Federal Senator.
div3.p:
Information reached this city on Saturday last, through refugees from the Western part of this State, that the bogus Pierpont Legislature had at its recent sitting in the city of Wheeling elected Lemuel J. Bowden, of Williamsburg, Va., to the United States Senate, to succeed Wallman T. Willey, the first incumbent under the bogus and usurped Government, whose term expired on the admission of the State of Kenawca into the Federal Union.
It is supposed that Lincoln's satellites refused to endorse Willey because he did not, as Senator, quite answer their expectations in an Abolition point of view.

div3.head: From Fredericksburg.
div3.p:
The Phillips House, about a mile from the Rappahannock on the Yankee side, from which Burnside conducted and overlooked the fight at Fredericksburg, was burned to the ground to-day about 2 P. M. It was the headquarters for some of the wretches, and doubtless, like the defeat, was the result of an "accident," although there were enough Yankees to be seen, with a good glass, all around it to have extinguished the fire.
It was recently built by A. K. Phillips, Esq., of Fredericksburg, at a cost of about $20,000, and was one of the most elegant establishments in this section.
What a pity it did not take fire at night, and burn up a number of its intruding and invading occupants.

About 3 o'clock this morning Yankee drums beat furiously, and continued until daylight, and some movement was going on. I hear a division made their appearance opposite Moss Neck, 16 miles below.
Some think they have had another panic in Washington since Friday, and have been moving up to head off Lee from their capital.

div3.head: Interesting incidents of the Galveston fight.
div3.p:
--The Richmond correspondent of the Jackson Mississippian announces the arrival here of Dr. Holland, of Texas, who participated in the fight at Galveston.
He brings with him the signal book of the Harriet Lane, which was found on the dead body of Capt. Wainwright, and was worn by him in the breast pocket of his coat, where it was pierced by the bullet of a navy revolver, discharged by Capt. Smith, whose second fire killed his antagonist.
The correspondent adds:

q.p:
Dr. Holland was one of the boarding party that cleared the decks of the Harriet Lane.
Some of the scenes and incidents he describes transcend in strange interest the narratives of Alexander Dumus.
Some years ago when the famous steamer Merrimac, afterwards changed into a ram by the Confederate Government, and forever memorable from her engagement with the Congress, Cumberland and Monitor in Hampton Roads, made her trial trip across the Atlantic, she entered, as well all remember, Southampton waters, and her officers were received with great hospitality by the authorities of Southampton.
Commander Wainwright was then the Merrimac's 1st Lieut.
and on going up to London was entertained by Dr. Holland, who was then living in the great metropolis.
The Doctor never saw him again alive, and recognized with a feeling of astonishment in the dead body of the commander of the Harriet Lane lying upon her decks, his guest of some years ago in London.
The saddest of all the terrible tragedies of this infernal war was enacted upon the same crimsoned and slippery stage when Major Lea, of the Confederate army encountered in the dying Lieutenant of the Federal steamer his own son. Can history or fiction afford and parallel to this?
It is a curious fact, too, which has not been stated that Capt. Leon Smith, to whose skill and gallantry Gen. Magrader attributes the entire success of the attack on the enemy's fleet in Galveston Bay is the brother of Caleb B. Smith, until very recently the Secretary of the Interior in Lincoln's Cabinet.
A gentleman, who only succeeded in making his escape from New Orleans two weeks ago, told Dr. Holland that he was in the same room with Farragat when the unwelcome intelligence of the loss of the Harriet Lane was announted to him, and that this functionary tore his hair with rage, declaring that it was the severest blow the Federal navy could have possibly received.
Farragat immediately dispatched four first-class steamers to retake the vessel if possible, otherwise to keep her shut up in Galveston harbor, but they arrived just a little too late.--Captain Leon Smith; with a volunteer crew, bad taken the Harriet Lane safely out to sea and Dr. Holland thinks it almost certain that it was this ship and not the Alabama or the Florida that sunk the Harteres and gave the Brooklyn her heels.
By a singular coincidence, with the departure of Farrugut's fleet Mr. Mallory had dispatched a commandant and other officers for the prize, but they also were a trific behind time.

div3.head: Convension of Mrs. Lincoln.
div3.p: --We have almost the highest official authority under the Government for stating that Mrs. Lincoln has at last become thoroughly anti-slavery — is hearty in her approval of the emancipation proclamation, and urges immediate and comprehensive arming of slaves who have been made free by it.
The foregoing important announcement is made by the New York Tribune with as much gravity as if we were about to be invaded by an army in — petticoats.

div3.head: Sambo as a prisoner.
div3.p: --A gentleman who left Memphis last Saturday furnishes the following paragraph to the Appeal:

q.p:
The negroes brought from Holly Springs, Grand Junction, &c. by Grant's army, are quartered in sheds in the vicinity of the Charleston depot, several thousand in number.
They are in a most wretched condition, suffering greatly from a lack of food and clothing, as well as the small pox and other potential classes.
The hardships they are compelled to endure are thinking out their numbers by scores.

div3.head: Eleven in thousand men Hors de Combat.
div3.p: --A Nashville correspondent of the Chicago Tribune, on the 23d ult., writes:

q.p: There are now in the nineteen hospitals in this city 8,000 patients, borides 1,200 to 1,500 that have been sent to the Ohio river hospitals, and as many more in the several hospitals at end near Murfreesboro'.

div3.head: Frightened to death.
div3.p:
--Mrs. Roo', wife of the township collector of DaKalb, was frightened to death last week by a man dressed in a white sheet with a coat wound around his head.
He knocked at her door in the evening.
She gazed for a moment at her horrid figure, and then fell backward to the floor lifeless.
The ghostly joker is a merchant of respectable standing.

div3.head: Printing office destroyed by a mob.
div3.p:
--The office of the Rockport (Ind.) Democrat was at tacked by a mob, compared of soldiers of the 5th Indiana cavalry, (a company of which is stationed near that place,) on Wednesday night, and the contents, with the exception of the press, destroyed.
Mr. Jones, the editor, estimates his loss at $100.

div3.head: Presses to death.
div3.p:
--The Classes Times says that is of the fleed at Came Bouglas to death on Sunday night last.
Upwards of 1,000 of them are sick.

div3.head: Go it while You're Young.
div3.p: --Two juvention named Jeroma Saunders and Lucy, Worth, the former aged sixteen and the latter fourteen, were married in Davies county, Kentucky, on the 9th
We have received the New York Herald and Washington Chronicle, of the 12th inst. The following is from the Herald's "Situation" articles:

Col. Fercy, Wyndbams reconnoitering party started from Stafford Court-House on the 9th, and cut the telegraph wires at Warrenton Junction captured two pickets at Fik Run, and round no rebels that side of the Rappahannock, and all the streams and roads in a condition that the enemy cannot move, no more than ourselves.

The reported destruction of the Brooklyn is an "absurd story, manifestly untrue."The bark Springbok was captured by the U. S. steamer Sonoma off the Bahamas, on the 3d, and arrived in New York on the 12th.
The Sonoma chased the Florida 35 hours. The ram Queen of the West, which passed the Vicksburg batteries, was set on fire by turpentine balls thrown from the rebel gunboat City of Vicksburg.
Cut of 120 shots 12 only struck the Queen.

The French Yellow Book shows that during the period of Butler's reigu New Orleans, the relations of the United States with France and other countries were as times in danger of a serious rupture.
The French Minister at Washington, it says, "protested against his conduct," and denounced to Mr. Seward the acts of General Butler, as calculated to compromise on the gravest manner, international relations, and perhaps to provoke serious conflicts.
After the issue of the General's proclamation of September 24th, Admiral Keynand, of the imperial Navy, was ordered from the North to New Orleans, to act "with the authority of his rank, and the firms as and fact habitual to him."

The Madred Epoca and other Spanish newspapers approve of the purport and spirit of Napoleon's letter to Gen. Forey respecting his plans for Mexico.
The Epoca says it confirms all its editor has said "touching the propriety of a common action" between Spain and France in the Republic.
The following telegrams in the Herald are dated Washington, Feb. 4th:

q.p:
Since the Yellow Book revelations the Republican Senators led by Grimos, swear they will push reward from his stool.
Thurlow Weed is trying to save him, but success is doubtful.
The Republican Senators are caucusing, and will present their antagonism to Seward formerly to the President.--Several are very intemperate in their threats in case of failure.
Seward will present a state paper on intervention that will be a bombshell to his persecutors.
The French Minister is preparing a paper for the U. S. Government embodying the views of Napoleon III.

div3.p:
It is probable the Senate will adopt Chase's banking measure.
Collamer defended the local banks.
A leading Republican said lately, they must keep up the war until the Democrats come into power, when they must settle it.

A higher tax is proposed on tobacco, playing cards, whiskey and luxuries generally.
The House is occupied in debating a reduction of fare upon the Washington horse railway from 5 to 3 cents.-- [Sugar, of Virginia, favored 5 cents.]
Gen. Butler is closeted with the President.--Banks's late order against encouraging slaves to desert their masters works in favor of Butler as the man for the Southwest.
Stonewall Jackson's chaplain is to be released from the old Capitol prison.

Mr. Seward has sent to the Senate a short, sharp, and decisive note, denying that the French Minister visited Richmond at his suggestion in April last, or at any other time. "He was not then nor has be or any other person ever been, authorized by this Government, or by the Secretary of State, to make any representations of any kind, or on any subject, to the insurrectionary agents, or so called authorities, at Richmond, or to hold any communication with them on behalf of this Government.
From the beginning of the present disturbances till the spring of 1863 this Department was charged with authority to grant passes through the lines of the Government forces, and Mercier applied for a pass, and got it; bore no communication to any of the insurgents.
Since the 4th of March, 1861 no communication, direct or indirect, formal or informal, has been held with the insurgents, their siners or . These statements are to be qualified as to circumstances concerning exchange of prisoners and other military matters."

The Herald republishes Mercier's letter to Thouvenel, of April 13, 1863 in which he says Seward told him he could very easily go to Richmond, and offered him a pass; that, not having foreseen such a thing he promised to reflect on it and undertake the trip "when it seemed in compliance with the desire of Seward." He also says, "It was understood, besides, that I should report to Mr. Seward only what I was authorized to repeat to him. Mr. S. said to me that I might add if I found an opportune occasion that, in his opinion, the North was animated by no sentiment of vengeance, and that for himself he should with pleasure" meet Southern Senators in the Senate again, &c.

The Herald has two and a half columns on the "splendid success of the dash" of the Union ram Queen of the West, which ran the blockade of Vicksburg by daylight, smashed the rebel gunboat Vicksburg, destroyed three provision steamers drew fire from Fort Hudson, and returned.

Commodore Bell, on board the Brooklyn, off Galveston, January 26th, says the Harriet Lane is within Galveston waters.
Rear Admiral Farragut is "rearing and charging" and "fretting his guts" generally about the capture of the Harriet Lane.
In his official report he says: "It is difficult to conceive a more pusillanimous surrender of a vessel to an enemy already in our power then occurred in the case of the Harriet Lane."

The Herald publishes Mr. Memminger's report in full, and says editorially, that the "money affairs of the Confederates have passed through nearly the same process as the finances of the Federal Government" But our available resources bear no comparison with the means at their disposal, and it asserts that "the solution of the great question involved in the war mainly depends upon the relative financial endurance of the two belligerents." We have paid off our deficit and about forty-two million floating debt, and, after defraying current expenses, had a surplus of about fifteen millions of which two and a half millions were in gold.
Our expenses have been eight and one-third millions per week, while the Federals was twenty one millions, per week.
It says our public debt December 31st, was four hundred and forty-three and a half millions--and on 1st July would be eight hundred millions — one-third less than the Federal war debt.

Our currency must be reduced by two thirds to save the Confederacy from financial ruin.
The Herald predicts that depreciation will increase till Confederate money is as worthless as the old continental notes and the French assignats.
A gold dollar North is worth $1.60 paper; with us it is worth $2.25 paper.
It says loans and Treasury notes will not raise half enough for such a gigantic war as the present.
The Herald "Mr. Memminger will have a very different story to tell from that which he anticipates.
The United States has California gold and superabundant breadstaffs.
Cotton is a king dethroned Corn is a king regnant, and that monarch is here.
Our resources are vastly superior in men and means to these of the rebels.
They are still as exhausted and inexhaustible.
All that is needed is intellect and to develop and organize them and give the rebellion its quietus before the falling of the leaf, certainly before the first week in December.
But judging from the past, we must our expectations are not very santine as to the future while the present Administration continues in power and we fear, therefore, we must look to a more distant period for the final triumph of the Union over its malignant enemies, North and South."
The Herald thinks operations will begin against Charleston and Savannah simultaneously.

John Van. Baren says "the South is determined not to return; and until their armies have power to resist and put us down till war must go on, and these who would attempt to stop it will be carried away by the torrent" Therefore, he thinks the Convention proposed by Indiana will be barren — He pronounces the emancipation proclamation a dead letter, a hut bag, and a stumbling block.
The Herald says it is only a tub thrown out to amuse the Abolition whale.
The Herald has the following rumor:

q.p:
We are warned, from rebel sources that it is possible on some fine morning, in one of the of the Rappahannock, the whole army of Gen. Hooker may be attacked and demolished by the impatient and hungry army of Gen. Lee.
But we apprehend that no such good luck can be expected as the voluntary appearance of his cautious veterans outside of their entrenchments.
We suspect they will stick fast behind their works until smoked out, out, or poked out; and we know that Gen. Hooker is ready, and that his soldiers are ready, to seize the opportunity of even a partial hardening of the mud in which they are now embargoed to open their road to Richmond.

div4.head: The intervention will-o'-the Wisp.
div4.p: The Washington Chronicle of the 12th, has the following dispatch, under the head of "A Sensation Report:"

q.p: New York Feb. 11.--The Express prints a Washington telegram, stating it is reported to-day that Secretary Reward has rejected the proposition of the French Emperor for the North and the South to appoint commissioners for consultation in Montreal or Mexico.

div4.p:
[A telegram from Philadelphia says the above publication caused great excitement in the money market yesterday afternoon, causing gold to advance from 152½ to 158½.
It subsequently fell, however, to 154½ No such reports were generally prevalent in Washington.]
The Europe, bringing the reported friendly mediation, arrived at is allfax on the 9th, and her mails have not yet reached Washington.

The editor of the Chronicle says it is absurd to suppose the Government would act formally upon a matter of such importance upon a newspaper report, which itself is open to doubt — that part of it which conference between the North and the South without the .

div4.head: Peace Propositions in the New Jersey Legislature
div4.p: The following dispatch is published in the Chronicle:

q.p:
Trenton Feb. 11.--Mr. D. Smith offered resolutions of a peace character, and one appointing six commissioners to proceed to Richmond to ascertain whether the States now in army against the U. S. Government will content to reaffirm their adhesion to the Union, and recognize the authority of the Constitution; and it not on what is conditions amiable relations under our U. S. Government can be restored between them and other States.
She invites the co-operation of sister States in the fraternal mission hereby created.

div4.p: A third set of resolutions say, while a con is going on at home, it is proper we appoint Gens. Humtide, and H. G. Chancellor, Commissioners, to urge on the Preside it sleepless vigilance, and determination to crush out this rebellion, and, if need be, call upon the people to come to the rescue of an imperilled and suffering nation.
A cancus is now holding to agree what policy shall be adopted amid these conflicting views.

div4.head: The price of a Seat in the U. S. Senate--Rich Exposure of Simon Cameron — curious history of a Bribery case.
div4.p:
The defeat of Simon Cameron the Abolition candidate for U. S. Senator, has been published, and the trick by which that defeat was accomplished briefly noticed.
It appears that one Democratic vote would have settled the matter, and Thos. J. Boyer, the Democratic member from Clearfield county, fearing that Cameron would buy some member who would vote for him, sold his vote to him for $20,000 and then east it against him, several of his colleagues being in the secret while the wire-working was going on. The Abolitionists were bitterly chagrined at the denouement.
The Harrisburg (Pa.) Union contains the letter from Mr. Boyer, giving an account of this remarkable transaction, from one portion of which it appears that Simon was willing to let the "erring sisters depart in peace." The following is the letter:

q.p:
As many rumors are afloat in regard to certain transactions which took place between Gen. Cameron and myself on several occasions previous to the late election of United States Senator.
I think it my duty to make a plain, unvarnished statement of the facts, so that there may be hereafter no misunderstanding or misrepresentation.
Believing that there would be attempts to bribe members in order to defeat the election of a Democrat.
I conceived the project of putting myself in the way of the operators, and trying how far they were disposed to go in the matter.
Once conceived, I determined to act upon it, and communicated my intention to several friends.
The first opportunity that offered Embraced — and here it the result:

div4.p:
I had been in Philadelphus, and on my return, perhaps a week or more before the election, I met Mr. Wm. Brobst of Lewisburg, with whom I was acquainted at the Pennsylvania house, in Harrisburg, for the first time this winter, and noticed some unusual nervousness on his part, and from his conduct was soon led to suspect that his business at Harrisburg was not of a very public character.
In the afternoon came to me and asked to see me privately, and we proceeded at once to my room, where he very soon commenced disparaging the several prominent Democratic candidates for United States Senator, and concluded by expressing his decided preference for Gen. Simon Cameron.

This, of course, left me no-room to doubt the object of his visit to the State capital and to me, and flat once asked him whether that was the object of his visit and he said it was. In reply to my question, whether Gen. Cameron authorized him to come to me in this way, he said he was authorized to see any Democrat of the House or Senate, and enter into the preliminary arrangements to secure a vote for Cameron.
I then asked him in what manner they expected to secure the election of Cameron.
He answered, "by getting three Democrats to absent themselves on the day of election"

I then asked him what they would pay. He said he was authorized by Cameron to offer five thousand dollars. I told him the figures were too low, and desired him to tell me who the other members were.
This he refused to do at the time, but would try and get permission of his principal to do so — He then left and returned in a short time, saying Gen. Cameron wanted to see me personally at his residence, out of the city, that evening.
I told him I could not make the engagement, but would answer him in one hour and, if I could get clear of another engagement I had made, I would go with him.

In the meantime I consulted with Dr. Early, of the House of Representatives, my colleague, to whom I related the foregoing facts.
I then saw Probat again, and told him I would go. He told me he would have a carriage ready in front of Herr's hotel at 7 o'clock; that he was authorized by Cameron to get a carriage at any time.
When the time arrived Dr. Early and myself walked down to Harr's and saw the carriage and Probat there.
I then made some excuse to Probat, and told him it would be best not to go. (I deemed it prudent at this stage of the proceedings not to manifest too much eagerness, lest I might defeat the object in view) The next day he (Probat) called and said that Cameron wanted to see me at the State Capital Bank.
I called, and was ushered into a back room of the bank, and found Cameron there alone.
He addressed me as follows: "Buyer, do you think you could have courage enough to vote for me?" I answered that this was a very business like question, and that it would depend very much on circumstances.
He then said, "Suppose the circumstances are all right!" I asked him how he meant " all right?" He answered "the financial consideration; in short, the dollars and cents" I answered him, "certainly." He then asked me what I would take.
I told him I had not been in this business long, and did not know exactly how to answer, but wished him to name the sum. He asked what I thought of $10,000 "right down, after the work was done." I then asked him whether he wanted a vote or an absentee.
He answered "a vote;" and that it would be very troublesome to get the men away, and, beside, he only regarded the money paid as the first instalment and that he felt in duty bound to take care of the person that made him Senator afterward and if he had so many to take care of it would embarrass him; but, if he had but one, he could do it well and profitably as long as we lived; and said, beside, there would be no more danger in voting directly for him than in being absent, for they would make every provision for the protection of the men that would vote for him.

This ended the interview, and we agreed to meet again to fix the compensation.
The next day he sent Probat for me I declined going to see him, but agreed to see him at my room No. 15 Pennsylvania house. Mr. Probat., who was still up to this time figuring for Simon, went after him, and in less than twenty minutes returned with him. Cameron then said, "Well let's come to an understanding" I said, "What for?" He answered " In references to the question."

I then said. "I must have $15,000" He said, "I will give it;" and wanted to know who I would prefer to arrange further interviews and do the financiering of the business.
I told him my knowledge of his friends did not enable me to name that person.
He then proposed him Burns.
I said he would do. He then left, staring that he was going to Philadelphia to arrange another matter which he had in view and would return on Saturday evening. This was on Wednesday.

On Thursday I met John J. Patterson.
He desired to see me and asked me to call at his room at Herr's hotel.
When I met him, I asked him where Burns was?
He told me he was sick.
He then said, "Boyer, the money will be allright." I asked him. "What money? " He then said, "Oh, I know all about it; I saw Cameron" (I must not forget to state here that, prior to my meeting Patterson, Probat told me Patterson wanted to see me on this business) and by Cameron's arrangement, he would go down in the ears on the Valley road Friday at 2 o'clock, and that we would go together and settle the entire affair.

We met according to arrangement and, in the baggage apartment of the New York concluded the bargain for $20,000 for a vote for Gen. Simon Cameron for the office of United States Senator, with the agreement that no other member should be bought, and that this should end the matter — provided Cameron would agree to the terms, and deposit the money in the hands of Patterson, to be paid to me immediately after the election was over and that the two members (with whom Patterson said Cameron was also in treaty) who were in the cars on their way to Philadelphia, should return on Saturday.

We considered the fact that, if they were sent off the House would not go into an election, and our agreement could not be consummated.
This statement seemed to determine his mind in favor of the arrangement.
Patterson went immediately to Cameron, who was in the car, and returned in a few minutes, stating that a though Cameron regarded the price beg he would pay it in order to save further trouble, and would, therefore, not say anything to the members then on their way to Philadelphia, and that they might return, and thus prevent any disarrangement of the plan that might arise from their absence.

Saturday evening was then agreed upon as the time for the next interview.
I stopped at Reading; so did Patterson, who returned that same evening to Harrisburg Cameron went to Philadelphia I came up on Saturday evening and found Cameron on the train, as well as at least one of the men who went to Philadelphia the day before, and I think both.
At the depot at Harrisburg I met Patterson, who said the interview would be at Dan Cameron's Accordingly, Patterson and myself went directly to the house, and found the General there ahead of us.

He invited us up stairs and, by a disme light, we agreed upon the price, v s: Cameron assented to the bargain between Patterson and myself by agreeing to pay the $20,000--$3,000 of which was to be paid in hand — and would it in Patterson's hands in my presence, at some future interview, subject to my inspection.
A little incident accurred here it would be a pity to loss to the world.

After the bargain was concluded Simon straightened up in his chair, rubbing his legs with his hands, saying: "Well, this ends it I will be Senator, and you will never regret it," (addressing himself to me) "I will be the most powerful men in that Senate: the entire state of affairs of this Government will be changed, nothing it move certain than that the South will going her independence (this sounded like treason) and then we will hold the control of the Government, and I will be able to serve my friends," and as we period again, to dream of Southern Confederates and Winnebagoes for Senator, Patterson and I then agreed to meet on Monday.

We met at 5 o'clock, in Patterson's room, at Herr's on Monday afternoon. Here Patterson told me he had the $5,000 hand money looked up in the safe down stairs, but wanted me to see Simon again before paying it ever to me. I insisted on the hand money.
This I deemed necessary to keep up the delusion.
We then period to meet at the same place early next morning.
Immediately after breakfast, on Tuesday, (the day of the election,) I met Patterson, according to agreement, at his room, Simon being present, lying on the bed, complaining of a of the bowels.

It was then desired that I should see some Abolition member of the Senate or House, who would be sent to me, and inform him of my willingness to vote for Cameron in case he was nominated.
To this I made some pretended objection, and demanded to know the necessity for it. Simon said it was this — that unless I did this they might thick he just wanted their d — d nomination for effect, which was not true.
He declared he would not have the nomination and a defeat for the whole Legislature.
So, of course, I consented, and the voting was voluntarily raised $5,000.

Patterson said the gentleman who would wait on me there was Dr. Fullor, of the Senate, who would be present as soon as I was ready to receive him. I said that was all right, but must now he convinced that the money was all right, too. Patterson then hurriedly showed me a large bundle of notes, which he represented as being the amount of the final payment.
He assured me the day before I should have the hand-money, and again on Tuesday morning I could have it.

I told him I deemed it better, on reflection, not to have it about me, in as much as there might be a row after the election, and said I would trust it to them, (Patterson and Cameron,) knowing them to be honest.
Patterson again assured me the hand-money was down in the safe, and, together with the resigns, should be election was over.
(I here state it did not come) Cameron then said his carriage would be in the State Capital Bank after the election, and I should come right down and go over to his house and remain there a while.
This, of course, I agreed to do, but did not.

Now, then, all things being arranged, Doctor Fulter was ushered in by Patterson.
The introduction completed, I said: "Doctor, I presume I understand the object of this interview." He then said: "I am chairman of a committee appointed by a Republican causes to wait on you to see whether you would vote for Cameron." I said: "Yes, I assure you that, if you nominate Gen. Cameron.
(pointing to the old Winnebage lying on the bed,) it will be all right." He said: "You give me that assurance?" I said: "Yes." Dr. F. then said: "You need have no fears of personal danger, or anything of that sort.
We have made every provision to meet all danger." Thus the last scene in this strange force ended Simon assured me that he would be ever grateful, and I hope he will.

It is proper here to say that during this entire adventure with Simon and his agents, my colleague, Dr. Earley; W. A. Wallace, the Senator from Clearfield; and Robert Vaughn, the proprietor of the Pennsylvania House, in this city, were in the secret, and Dr. Earley, especially, knew constantly what was going on.

In one of my interviews with Patterson, on the cars going to Reading, he said, in case there should any investigation grow out of the transaction, he would be the only witness that knew anything about it, and he would swear falsely and put it through.
In regard to the dates given in the above statement, as I made no memoranda at the time, I cannot be certain that they are correct, but I believe they are.

div4.head: An assault upon "the Nigger" in Baltimore.
div4.p:
A great deal of excitement was caused in Baltimore on the 6th instant, by an indiscriminate attack made on the negroes at the Northern depot by the Yankee soldiers.
The Sun has the following guarded account of the affair:

q.p:
A large number of convalescent soldiers, under an armed guard, were placed in cars yesterday morning at the Camden street depot, and the cars attached to the freight train that leaves the depot for Washington just after the 10 o'clock passenger train.
While the soldiers were a waiting the departure of the train, many of them got out of the cars and attacked every colored person that came within their reach.
They also provided themselves with brickbats and threw at every colored person they could see; some of these last were in their houses along the line of the track, and doors were broken and windows smashed by the stones, but no one was seriously hurts.
The guard appeared unable to control the riotous soldiers.

div4.head: A French view of the Charleston blockade.
div4.p:
The question whether or not the Charleston blockade has been raised continues to excite comment.
The French Courier, published in New York, which probably foreshadows French ideas, reviews the facts, and remarks:

The code of public right is timely and conclusive upon this point; that the moment the blockade of a port has been interrupted through the even momentary dispersion of the blockading squadron by a superior force, the victorious party has the right to proclaim the raising of the blockade, and the re-opening of the place thus made free to the commerce of the world.
From the moment that such declaration has been made, officially, foreign ports which receive such intelligence recover the right to forward their ships to the port the blockade of which has been represented as raised; and even if these ships reach there after the blockade has been re-established, they cannot be seized not confiscated, as they had left their respective ports for one which, at the moment of their departure had been declared free.
To stop the effects of this privilege, it is not only necessary that the blockading fleet reappears before the port from which it has been previously chased away, but a formal declaration of a new blockade is ordered, as the first blockade ceases to exist the very moment it has been broken by force.

In other words, or rather to make the general doctrine apply to the case before us: Suppose that the proclamation of Beauregard and Ingraham, with the news of their victory, reaches Nassau the 5th of this month, the ships which are there awaiting a chance to reach a Southern port can immediately go to sea and try the experiment, without running any other risk, on arriving before Charleston, than to ascertain that the blockade has been re-established.
Seizure nor conflication awaits their, when they can-establish before an Admiralty Court the fact that they have under taken their voyage upon the strength of the Beauregard and Ingraham proclamation.
And this state of things will last until the Washington Government has made a new announcement of the re-establishment of the blockade.

div4.head: Congress.
div4.p: The Senate is discussing the currency question.

In the House, notice was given of a bill repealing the laws levying duties on railroad iron and coal.
Bills concerning the admission of Nevada and Colorado were reported.

div4.head: Miscellaneous.
div4.p:
General Tom Thomb was married to Miss. Lavinia Warren, on Tuesday last, at Grace Church, New York city.
The police kept back the crowd.
General Burnside and other notabilities were present.
A platform, with six steps, was erected in front of the channel.
The bride and groom created great excitement on their arrival and appearance, but went through the ceremony with perfect ease and self-possession, and, yet, earnest seriousness, which showed that to them, at least, it was no farce.
After the ceremony the little creatures marched down the middle side, and were driven to the Metropolitan.

The New York World's correspondent, of the Army of the Potomac, says 259 desasters are now awaiting trial and a number will probably be shot.
Near Kelly's Ford the rebels have been busy repairing a railroad bridge across the Rappahannock.
After driving several trains across on Wednesday, a corps of cavalry started, but were driven back by the Unionists.
Several were killed.
The rebels then destroyed the bridge on their side and the Unionists on thens.

The Army of the Potomac has at intervals occupied something like 32 square miles, at least 4 of which was when it came there, covered with dense woods, mostly oak and cedar.
Where this forest stood there is new naught but one vast field, covered with stumps.

From Commander Eliots official report to Admiral Porter, of the ram Queen of the West, passing the batteries at Vicksburg, we learn his attempt to destroy the rebel vessel City of Vicksburg failed.
The current interfered with his momentum, and his vessel catching fire, he had to leave; was struck twelve times, but no material damage.
One gun was dismounted and ruined.

Chicago, Feb. 11.--The Queen of the West has returned from below.
She destroyed three rebel steamers with provisions for Vicksburg, took 56 prisoners--one Colonel.
She went near enough to draw fire from Fort Hudson.
It is possible Grant will make the canal successful.

New York Feb. 11--The U. S. steamer Somers captured a prize off the Haliamas and chased the Florida for 36 hour.
The Florida is reported to have made several prices off Cuba and one off the Bahamas.
The Alabama put into Kingston with the prisoners from the Hatteras.
She had several shots through her. Six U. S. war vessels are waiting for her.

Simon Fietsher, of Richmond, Woundfield and Bouenthal, of Baltimore; W. A. Semon, of Westmoreland; B. K. Buchanan, and G. Burkins, blockade runners, have been arrested.
Twenty-five thousand dollars in gold were taken with them.

The Chronicle, in an article on the Conservatives who want revolution, says wherever the Democracy has triumphed in the late elections in such a city as New York, or Legislatures as Albany, In disappoints, Baltimore, and Springfield, the have commenced, and in some instances perfected, direct and defiant resolutions.
Contempt it continues, for Federal authority has been as common as expressions of sympathy with traitors.
Reinforcements were constantly going up the Cumberland to Fosteraux, and it is believed he has accumulated sufficient provisions at Nashville to make a forward movement possible.
A verdict for $572 damages has been obtained by the proprietors of the Philadelphia Jeffersonian against the U. S. Marshal, for their paper for disloyalty.

On the 12th gold sold for 152½ rallied to 156½ then 155½ and closed at 154 ¼ Exchange; sold at 148½ but was held at 171½ in the afternoon.
Cotton advanced to 92@93 cent, middlings; 700 bales sold.
A collision occurred recently on the Northriver--one steamer was sunk and a number of persons (six men at least) were scalded to death.
A London subterranean railway has been opened in London, four miles long tunneling the busiest streets in the heart of the city.

Col. Cushman, of Tenn.
the noted cotton burner, has been arrested and carried to Ohio.
He had no commission.
The New York Senate has adopted resolutions endorsing the President's emancipation proclamation.
From San Francisco on the 12th, the Constitution sailed with $104,000 in treasure for England, and $3,120,000 for New York.

In Ireland there is extreme poverty and a gloomy future.
The distress was "unprecedented."
Six hundred and fifty bales of cotton had arrived from Paralbs, coast of Brazil.
Gen. Hulburt, at Memphis, has prohibited the circulation of the Chicago Times.
The army corps under Gen. Smith has gone to Fortress Monroe.

--This body met at 12 o'clock M, Mr. Johnson in the Chair.
Prayer by the Right Rev. Bishop Early, of the Methodist Episcopal Church.
A number of Senate bills were reported back from the House and the amendments concurred in by the Senate and the bills referred.

Bills Introduced.--A bill authorizing the connection of certain railroads within the city of Richmond; a bill for the relief of Zachariah L. Finney, of Pittsylvania county; petition of Mrs. Mary S. Bagley, concerning the valuation of a condemned slave by the County Court of Lunenburg.
Mr. Robertson asked leave to introduce the following bills; A bill to abolish the Board of Public Works and transfer their duties elsewhere; a bill to abolish office of vaccine agents, and transfer their duties to the University of Virginia; a bill to abolish the office of Weights and Messures and transfer their duties to the Land Office.
The bill authorising the appointment of county agents and storekeepers was called up, on motion of Mr. Cogbill, and made the order of the day for Thursday next.

The bill increasing the salaries of the Secretary of the Commonwealth and other officials and clerks of the State Government was put upon its passage and last — ayes 19, noes 13-no constitutional majority voting.
A reconsideration of the vote laid the bill upon the table.

A message from the Executive, transmitted in response to a resolution of the Senate, alleged insufficiency of railroad transportation as the reason for the non fulfillment of the salt contract with the Smythe and Washington Salt Works, for the supply of the Congressional districts.
Referred to the special Committee on Salt.
A number of bills were read the second and third time and laid upon the table, the Senators interested in their prosecution to a passage being absent.

Bills Passed--A bill in relation to the sale of free negroes.
A bill amending an ordinance of the Convention extending the jurisdiction of the County Courts in certain cases.
The resolution by which the Senate voted to meet on and after Monday at 11 o'clock A. M., was reconsidered and laid on the table.
On motion, the Senate adjourned.
[The Chair stated to the Senate that the Senator from Jefferson, Mr. Isbell, had been compelled to return to his home by reason of continued illness in his family]

div4.head: House of delegates.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock. Prayer by Mr. Walker.
Mr. Jones, from the Committee on Courts submitted a report extending the time of prosecution in criminal cases in counties held by the enemy.

Mr. Hunter, from the Select Committee appointed to inquire into the loyalty of Judges, and the impeachment of Judge J. E. Pitts, asked to be discharged from the consideration of the subject at this time.
Mr. Hunter stated that when the gentleman who submitted the resolution (Mr. Garrison) returned to the House, he would state the reasons for making the request.

Resolutions of Inquiry.--The following resolutions of inquiry were introduced: By Mr. Magruder: Into the expediency of authorizing the Monticello Bank to increase its contingent fund.
By Mr. Treadway: Into the expediency of incorporating the Farmville Insurance Company.
By Mr. Bigger: Into the expediency of reporting a bill for the payment of Mr. Exall for a plan changing the Hall of the House of Delegates.
By Mr. Magruder: Into the expediency of so amending section 34, chapter 184, of the Code of 860, as to increase the compensation of Clerks and Sheriffs for public duties performed by them.
By Mr. Fleming: Into the expediency of amending the Code so as to provide a more summary mode for the trial of horse thieves.

Mr. Prince submitted a resolution, which was agreed to, requesting the Governor to communicate to the House the compensation received by Dr. J. J. Moorman as State Agent for the delivery of salt at Saltville, and also of agents for each district.

Mr. Pitman moved to take up the resolution offered by him on yesterday, relative to changing the hour of meeting for the House from 12 to 11 o'clock. The motion was agreed to and the resolution passed.
Mr. Reld offered a resolution, which was laid over, that when the House adjourns on the 26th inst., it adjourn sine die.

Mr. Burks submitted a resolution, which was agreed to calling upon the Governor to communicate to the House the number of negro convicts employed in the iron or other works of the State, under acts passed April, 1858, and December, 1861, concerning negro convicts on the public works, and under what contracts and what rules and regulations have been employed to secure their safe keeping while so engaged.

On motion of Mr. Hunter the rules were suspended, and the substitute for bill No. 74 entitled "an act to amend and re-enact an act passed May 17, 1863, entitled an act to authorise a force of 10,000 men to be raised for the defence of the Commonwealth." was taken up and considered.

[The bill authorizes the Governor, as soon as practicable, to reorganize the State troops raised under the ants of 15th and 17th of May, 1862, and under command of Gen. J. B. Floyd by consolidating companies squadrons, &c, and otherwise rearranging said troops so as to make such reorganization conform to the requirements of an act of Congress of the Confederate States, entitled an act to provide for the public defence, approved March 6, 1861, or any subsequent act, as fully as if said troops had been originally organized under the authority of the Confederate Government.
It further empowers the Governor, in carrying out the provisions of the act, to retire from the services of the State such of the officers, both company and regimental now in commission under authority of said acts of Assembly, as shall, by the process of said reorganization, have become supernumerary, retiring or retaining such officers at his discretion as the reorganization may require.]

Mr. Cazenove moved the following amendment to the bill, which was agreed to: Provided That nothing contained herein shall be so construed as to direct payment to be made to any officer not authorized to draw pay under the acts of May 15th and May 17th, 1862.
The bill, as amended, was ordered to its engrossment.
Mr. Bradford submitted the following resolutions:

q.p: Resolved, by the General Assembly of Virginia, That the Governor of the Commonwealth had no authority to commission officers of the State Line, except such as is conferred by the act entitled "an act to authorize a force of 10,000 men to be raised for the defence of the Commonwealth," passed May 15, 1862.

div4.p: 2d. Received, That the Paymaster General of the State of Va. is hereby instructed to pay only such officers of the State Line at have been commissioned in accordance with the provisions of said act.
Objection being made, the resolutions were laid over.

Mr. Fleming submitted a resolution asking the Senate to return House bill passed yesterday concerning Aids to the Governor.
The motion gave rise to some discussion, and finally, the vote being taken upon it by ayes and nose, it was defeated — ayes 31, noes 59.

Bills Passed.--Increasing the powers of Circuit Courts in cases of attachment of property belonging to non-residents; changing certain sections of the Code so as to exempt from distress for sent payable in money the property of persons engaged in the military serves of the country; authorizing the Branch of the Exchange Bank at Richmond to declare a dividend; authorizing the payment to B. E. and J. W. Ceely the sum of $400 for a slave condensed to be hung but who died prior to execution; legalizing the records, proceedings, and acts of the County Court of Spotsylvania he'd during the year 1860 at places other than the Court-House of said county; incorporating the Submarine Battery Joint Stock Company, for blowing up the enemy's frigates, gunboats, etc., according to the plan of Jobs a Smith, of Petersburg.
On motion of Mr. Forben, the House adjourned.

div3.head: Mitigation of Services.
div3.p: --The order dispanding Col. Thos. Ford, of Harports Ferry time of the volunteer (Ohio) service, has been resident, and he is discharged on sender of his resignition from the 8th of November last, so says an army order.

div3.head: Very Latest from the North.
div3.p: --The Herald, of the 13th, is received.

It says a movement to settle the present difficulties by a Convention of representatives of the free States is progressing in the West The Illinois Legislature has appointed a committee to confer with there of Indiana, Kentucky and other Sister, at Louisville in the month of March--the foremost on the committee being a strong adherent of Lincoln and heretofore a strong Republican.
Logan, the gentleman in question, urged all his friends to vote the Democratic ticket in November last, to save the country.
Other eminent Republicans are on the same committee.
The measure was proposed in the main by Abolitionists.
It is expected that Ohio, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and New York will combine in the movement.

The Wahawken (iron clad) arrived at Port Royal is tow of the United States gunboat Landons.
She made the passage under great difficulties the weather being quite temp. Hunter hs issued orders conscripting all able-bodied negroes in his department.
The Alabama was heard from in latitude 25.30 on the 2d of February.
Peace resolutions passed the Illinois Legislature, on the 12th, 52 to 23.
Wilson said in the U. S. Senate, on the 12th that the Army of the Potomac has 300 regiments and $100,000 men, in the Murfreesboro' fight, had 140 regiments, and 45,000 men.
Young Williamson, of Baltimore, Secretary of Mason, our English Minister, has been sent to Fort McHenry, at Seward's instance.
Gov. Spragne has been elected Senator from Rhode Island.
Resolutions inviting Gen. McClellan to visit Albany, as the guest of the State, have passed the New York Legislature.
Gen. Pope is in St. Louis, and is expected to command the expedition to Vicksburg.
Pecuniary aid to Missouri, to emancipate her slaves, passed -23 to 18.

Montaner Territory has been organized by a vote of the U. S. House of Representatives.
It lies contiguous to Washington and Oregon.
The Yankee army is to have twenty more Major Generals and fifty more Brigadier Generals.

argument.p: Grand Programme for Terminating the war, and Forming a Northwest Confederacy.

div4.p:
--The Southern Crisis, of the 11th inst., learns from a distinguished citizen of one of the Northwestern States, that Indians Lincols, and Ohio, have determined to stop the war and make terms of peace with the Confederate States, at all hazards.
They are resolved that the war against the Confederate States shall cease; otherwise the Northwest will make war against the aggressors.
The citizens of those States, drafted or enrolled, are leaving the Federal army by hundreds and regiments, and there is an authority to control this movement, of 350,000 men under General McClernand only 40,000 effective soldiers remain.
That number is daily diminished by mortality from sickness and voluntary abandonment.

The Legislatures of Illinois; Indiana, Ohio, and Kentucky, will convene at Frankfort, in general convention, an the 18th of February, to agree upon the institution of a Northwest Confederacy, propose, terms of peace and commerce with the Confederacy, for the States bordering on the Mississippi and its tributaries; proposing a treaty offensive and defensive with the South, or an adoption of the Confederate States Constitution, and incorporation of those new members into the Confederacy, if agreeable to the people of the Confederate States; but in any event relations of amity and commerce with the South.
Commissioners will bear the result to Richmond, to treat with the Confederate Government for a final and satisfactory adjustment.
All interests require that this action should be taken openly, with a serious and dignified determination.

The terms of adjustment will be submitted for ratification to the people of Ohio, Indiana, and Illinois at the ballot box, and when thus ratified, separation from the United States will be irrevocably perfected.

This informant says that he expects no more general engagements.
By the 1st of April there will be a practical cessation of hostilities in the Southwest, and by 1st of June permanent peace, unless the Republicans wage war against the Northwest.

div3.head: From Vicksburg.
div3.p:
--The enemy is reported to be actively engaged in throwing up batteries on the Louisiana shore, with the supposed purpose of protecting their men when they commence throwing pontoon bridges across the river.
This report, however, is not believed here.
Our authorities appear to anticipate an early attack, and our forces are prepared for the enemy night or day. All quiet now.

div4.head: [second Dispatch.]
div4.p:
--One of the enemy's gunboats passed our batteries last night, at 12 o'clock, under cover of the darkness.
Several shots were fired at her, but none is believed to have taken effect.
All quiet this morning.

div3.head: Offenders against the Confederacy.
div3.p: --The following battles were lodged in the Military Prison of the Eastern District, on Saturday, viz: Mr. Kirby, for piloting deserters through the country; L. Shiflet, for persuading his sons to desert from the army and stealing ammunition with which they could defend themselves; Leak Shiflet of company D, 46th Va. regiment, and Wm. Catterion, of the same company and regiment, for desertion.

div3.head: Arrests.
div3.p:
--The city police arrested two offenders on Saturday night--Joseph H. flay, for setting drunk and behaving disorderly in the Theatre and Wm. Graser, for assaulting and beating George Engel about the head with his fist.
The city was very quiet yesterday.

div3.head: Military Parade.
div3.p:
--The 10th and 18th Virginia battalions and a part of Major De Laguiel's battalion, paraded on the Capital square, on Saturday, with full ranks, in the presence of a large concourse of people.
The force was in charge of Col. Thos. G. Rbett, assisted by Lieu.
Col. Atkinson and Major Housley.
The men were well-clothed and shoed in their evolutions the affect of soldierly discipline.

div3.head: Court proceedings.
div3.p: --James Gibbons was arraigned for stealing a pair of shoes, worth $15 from Michael Golden, on Broad Street. He was remanded to jail to await an indictment by the Hustings Court Grand Jury.

John Moore was required to answer for assaulting and beating Simon Jacobs, at the Spotswood House.
The wounded man being in a dangerous condition, of course did not appear and the case was continued until Tuesday.
It appears that Moore made an attempt to rob Jacobs, which the letter detected and resisted.
Moore then seized'd bar of iron, which happened to be hear, and dealt his victim such a blow that the shall was fractured, and-death will likely Defendant is a rough looking fellow, and a recent importation into the city.

Margaret slave of George Williams, was arraigned, charged with stealing a $100 C. S. Treasury note from Mr. John W. Davies.
The Mayor sent her on for final trial before the Hustings Court.

Ruben Kelhearte, a German, arrested for the alleged larceny of a plated worth $75, from John Cooley, underwent as examination and was honorably acquitted.
It appeared that he bought the pistol from a party that he had every right to suppose was its legal owner, though such was not the case.

Wm. Henes a lad, was arrested at the Theatre Friday night and brought before the Mayor, for introducing a of indifferent whiskey into the second tier of that establishment, handing the same in a tin cup to visitors to the manifest determent of good order.
The the used introduced an evidence against the useful marchant.
He was committed in default of security for his good behavior.
similar charge was brought were required to give security for their good behavior.
The ones against Milly, slave of Dral Locke, charged with stealing clothing from Mrs. Agnes Biglow, was partly heard and continued until Monday.

William H. Murphy, a bogus captain, arrested by the military notice, was partly beard on the charge of swindling various people by receiving men as substitutes into an imaginary company commanded by himself.
The case was continued until Monday.

Wm. Henry Ross and John Roberts were examined for having violently dispossessed Albert a slave of $22, near the Old Market-House.
The witness gave a very clear statement as to how the robbery was performed but other witnesses introduced on behalf of the defendants were equally as clear that Albert wagared the money and lost it — The examination was continued.
Hustings Court Saturday Feb'y 14. --Present: Recorder Caskle and others.

James G. Davis was tried by jury for assaulting and beating Laren Lewis, a resident of Broad st. The result being proved, and no justification of the affair offered by the defendant he was found guilty, and the term of his imprisonment in the city jail a certained at two months in additions to this he was fined $35 and ordered to be retained in prison till he should liquidate the amount.
The case against Wm. H. Bryce, for an alleged unlawful assault on Ann. Larkin Shannon, was partly heard, and continued to the next term of the Court for final trial.

The case of Albert G. Sloblair, charged with forging the name of Mrs. Nancy Mathins to a permit authorizing the o'clock of the Hustings Court to issue him a license to marry her daughter was continued till the next term, and the prisoner remanded to jail.

All other cases not disposed of were continued.
The Court adjourned on Saturday.

div3.head: English gunpowder for the Confederacy.
div3.p: One of the English papers has lately stated that Great Britain Shipped about thirteen millions of pounds of gunpowder, the first three months of 1862 to the South.
Col. Alfred E. Jackson, of Jonesboro', has received the appointment of Brigadier-General.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 40, page 2.

div3.head: Remittances to the Dispatch.
div3.p:
--We have made arrangements with the Southern Express Company by which all money for subscription, advertising, or job work, can be sent at our risk.
The money to be sent should be enclosed to an envelope, directed to the "Richmond Dispatch, Richmond, Virginia," and seated with wax, writing the subscriber's name, post-office, and amount sent on the outside.
Deliver the same to any agents of the Southern Express Company, and take his receipt.
Send a letter to the office of the Dispatch by mail, advising us of the date when sent.
Our agents will observe carefully these directions, and follow them.

div3.head: Type wanted.
div3.p:
--The proprietors of this paper wish to purchase 1,000 or 1,500 pounds of Nonpareil or Agate Type.
The highest price will be paid.

div3.head: The news from the Northwest.
div3.p:
We publish in another column the astonishing news from the Northwest, received by the telegraph on Saturday.
We call it astonishing.
It is something more.
It is amazing, astonading, stupefying.
Illinois, Indians, and (we believe) Ohio, have determined to put a step to the war — to offer Lincoln the alternative of peace or Secession — to recall their soldiers — to play the d--1 in a variety of ways.
Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, have done this.
Not a portion of the people of Indiana, Illinois, and Ohio--not a party in the Legislature — not a party in the country — not primary meetings or meetings of delegates representing bodies of people — but the States themselves in solid column, assembled God knows where, and speaking God knows how, or through what organ!
Their manner of proceeding, it seems, it to be as distinguished for wisdom as it has already been for unanimity.
They send delegates — what they want with delegates, when they have already settled matters without them, we do not know — they send delegates — not to any point within their own borders — but of all other places upon earth, to Frankfort, where bodies of troops are already superintending the proceedings of the Kentucky Legislature, and where legislative committees deliberate with sentinels at the door of the committee room — These delegates, from this very safe and convenient point of assemblage, are to send other delegates to Richmond, having first ascertained, of course, that the way is safe, the coast clear, and that the Yankee soldiers and officers will open their ranks and let them pass, whether they possess passports from the Federal authorities or not. The physic, it seems, is already working.
Out of McClernand's army of 150,000, all have deserted but 40,000--the biggest desertion of modern times, except in a few cases where a whole army have gone over, as the Saxons at Leipsic — and 110,000 late Union soldiers are struck at a single blow, without firing a shot or drawing a sword, from the best of the Union army!
Well might the telegraph call these marvels "important, if true!"--We wonder at its moderation in thus designating them.
Even the concurrent announcement that McClernand — after the loss of his 110,000 deserters — is still stirring heaven and earth to take Vicksburg, does not add to the astounding character of the tidings!

To the credit of this community, be it said we have not met with a man who placed the slightest confidence in this bald, disjointed, palpable humbug, the author of which appears to be a mere apprentice to the trade of lying.
The very extravagance of the statements deprived them of all power to deceive by removing all possibility of belief.
Yet had there been the least shadow of probability attached to them, they were calculated to produce infinite harm.
The public is predisposed to attach too much credit to the reports which we constantly hear from the Northwest, and while we are threatened by a host almost rivalling that of Xarxes, to look for safety in the divisions and distractions of our enemies, instead of expecting it from the only source from which it can possibly come, namely: from the valor and constancy of the men who are upholding our banner in the field.
That there is discord in the councils as well as in the ranks of the enemy, we have every reason to believe; yet not more than a single victory on a large scale, and of a decided character, would instantly have; not more than the assurance of the conquest and spoliation of the South would convert into perfect unanimity.
If parties quarrel in the North, it is because their armies are unsuccessful in the South.
If one of these parties speaks out loudly for peace, it is became it sees no profit likely to arise from the prosecution of the war. Let them but have a few decisive victories in the South, and we shall soon find our cause in a miserable minority in the North.
In the meantime, we believe this constant delusion to be hurtful to our cause.
We believe, indeed, nothing could be more so. It raises hopes that are destined to be extinguished as fast as they are raised, and the disappointment of hope is worse than not entertaining hope in the beginning.
It is a condition of mind the worst possible for recruiting our armies.

Let us not be understood as impugning the policy of widening every breach which may occur between parties in the enemy's country by every means possible.
It would clearly be folly in us not to take every advantage that presents itself to us. But let us not depend upon that resource as the means of conquering our independence.
That must be done at the point of the bayonet and the mouth of the cannon, and that fact ought always to be kept in view.
Anything that interferes with our military arrangements, therefore, we hold to be injurious to our cause; and this constant system of delusion has that effect.
It damps the ardor of the population, and takes away the spirit of the conscript, who ought to go into the war under the belief that he will have to fight it out, and that he is to expect nothing from any other source than his own valor.

div4.p: On the 29th January, 1863, at the residence of Mr. Bowman, Franklin street, by Rev. T R Edwards, Mr. Alex L. Cox to Miss Mary F. Price, of Madison county.

On the evening of the 12th instant, in this city, by Rev. Jas.
E Gates, Mr. Augustus A Froget to Miss Allen Heaxron. *
On Sunday morning, 15th instant, at 6 o'clock, Victoria Beauregard, only daughter of S J and G H Arnall aged one year one month and four days.

lg.l: Dearest Vac, thou hast left us.
We thy foss most deeply feel,
But 'tis God who bath bereft us,
He can all our sorrows heal.
Victoria, again we hope to meet thee,
When the day of life has lied;
Then in Heaven, with joy to greet thee,
Where no farewell tears are shed.

div4.p: The friends and acquaintances are invited to attend her funeral this afternoon at 3 o'clock, from her father's residence, on Broad, between Foushee and Adam sts, without further notice.
On the 14th instant, after a severe spell of sickness of ten days, Harriet Willie, second daughter of Henrietta and Wm. G. Valentine, aged 12 years and 8 months.
She was a devoted child to her parents, and beloved by all who know her. Her last words to her mother were trust in God.

lg.l: Rest, sweet Harriet, O, our love,
Since we are doomed to part;
That took you from our hearts.

div4.p: Her funeral will take place from her father's residence on Oregon Hill, this (Monday) evening, at 3 o'clock.
At his father's residences in Manchester, on Friday night, Feb'y 13th, Archibald C, youngest son of A C and Maria E Gibbs, aged 13 months and 12 days.
Petersburg Express please copy.

div3.head: Fifty dollars Reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay fifty dollars for the arrest and lodgment in a safe jail of my men George, if takes out of the city of Richmond or county of Chesterfield, or $50 reward if taken to those He left my house, in Manchester, on Saturday last, about 12½ o'clock P. M. He is about six feet high, 2d years old; brown color, and weighs about 190 pounds. He had on when he left a brown frock coat, and was well dressed generally.
He carried a bag of clothes with him. He came from near Danville, and is probably trying to get back.
He may hire himself to work in some camp, or try to get off on the He had on a good black hat.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--To go in one of the best infantry companies in service.
He must come well recommended, and be over 45 years of age, for which a liberal price will be paid.
For further particulars address "G R B" Co F, 4th Georgia regiment, Hamilton's Crossing, Va. *

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--One over 45 years of age, of good character, and sound health.--The highest price will be given.
Apply at No. 151 Main street, Riddle's Ambrolype Gallery.

div3.head: Substitute notice.
div3.p: --Any gentleman wishing a Substitute may be supplied by calling at E D Eacho's office, from 9 to 3 o'clock, by a reliable man.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--Wanted, a Substitute, to go in a No. 1 artillery company None need apply unless he is over 45 years old, sound and healthy, and with a character well endorsed.
For such an one a liberal price will be paid.
A Virginian preferred.
Apply at the office corner of Wall and Franklin sts, to Clopton & Lyne,

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--$2,000 will be given for a sound and reliable man over 45 years of age, to go as a Substitute in a No. 1 infantry company.
Apply at the Saw Mill, Mayo's Bridge.

div3.head: Beautiful Improved farm, near Charlottesville, and twelve or fifteen Negroes, for Sale.
div3.p:
--In obedience to a decree of the Circuit Court of Albemarle, pronounced in the chancery suit of "Henderson and wife vs Crawford and als," the undersigned Commissioners will offer for sale, at public auction, on the premiere on Tuesday the 3d day of March, 1863, (or the next for day,) a beautiful estate known an Meadow Cleek, containing about 600 acres. This farm within a mile of Charlottesville, and lies than a mile from the University of Virginia; has an abundance of timber; is smooth and gently undulating of a high disgrace of improvement; has a large creek passing entirely through the place, affording a quantity of fine meadow, well in old grass yielding a large county of hay; and there is repairing of running water in every field.
There is an excellent dwelling- house, and all the necessary out-houses, and a fine peach orchard on the place.
It is seldom that so desirable a place, in the immediate vicinity of a large town, in offered for sale.
Will be sold at the same time and place, 12 or 15 likely Negroes, Household and Kitchen Furniture, a fine Piano, two good Mitch Cows, &c.
Terms.--Pretty much of the option of the purchaser.

div3.head: By Hill, Dickinson & Co., Auct's.
div3.p:
Receiver's Sale of Negroes.--By virtue of two decrees of the District Court of the Confederate States, in and for the Eastern District of Virginia I shall, on Monday, the 14th instant at 10 o'clock, at the auction rooms of Hill, Dickson & Co., sell for cash, four Slaves, consisting of a man, a boy, and two woman.
One of the women is said to be a good Cook.

div3.head: Wanted — Negroes.
div3.p: --We still wish to hire able-bodied negro men and Boys to work at our blast furnaces in Rockbridge and Scteto counties, and at our coal mines near this city.--Those having hands on the fortifications whose terms of service will soon expire, can procure good homes for them by early application to us.
div3.closer:
J R Anderson & Co,
Tredegar Iron Works. fe 15--1w

div3.head: Wanted — an Overseer.
div3.p:
--The advertiser desires to employ, immediately, an Overseer, to take charge of a farm in Henrico county.
He must be well recommended for sobriety and qualifications.
A married man, with a small family, preferred.
Apply to
div3.closer:
A D Williams, 11th street,
Bet. Main and Bank sts. fe 16--3t

div3.head: Wanted — old Axes — old Axes.
div3.p:
--I wish to purchase any quantity of old Axes, for which the highest cash prices will be paid.
Also, 10,000 pounds of old Brass.
Apply immediately.
div3.closer:
W F Jenkins,
In Cary Alley, near corner of 14th and Cary sts. fe 16--6t*

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A situation as Manager of a small farm by a middle-aged man without encumbrance.
The best of references given as to character and industry.
Any communication left with Jas. L. Apperson, Esq. will be attended to.

div3.head: Wanted — a Teacher.
div3.p:
--I wish to employ a Teacher to take charge of a School in Chesterfield county.
She must be well qualified to teach French, Music, and the usual English branches.
My address is Manchester P. O.

div3.head: Wanted — Weavers.
div3.p:
--Woolen Weavers can get employment at the mills of the Manchester Cotton and Wool Manufacturing Company, at full rates of wages.
Apply at the Factory.

div3.head: Wanted — to boy
div3.p:
--For a Nurse, a middle aged family Servant, neat in be habits and of good disposition.
Apply at No. 111 Main st.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--An Engineer to run a saw mill, a short distance from the city.
Apply at
div3.closer:
Dr. Chas E Anderson's,
Cor Clay and Fentbee sts. fe 16--1t*

div3.head: Wanted — Carpenters
div3.p: --We wish to hire two negro Carpenters by the year.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Furnished room or two, for which a liberal price will be paid.
For particulars address "Box 249," city Post-Office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--Odd Fellows', Druida, Masonia, or other Regalia, worked with good.
Also, gold Fringes, at No. 35 Main street up stairs.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A steady white man, to work on a farm.
Apply at 188 Main streets.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--An Engineer to run a saw mill, a short distance from the city.
Apply at Dr. Chas E Anderson's, corner of Clay and Fonshee sts.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Virginia Lady, of some years' experience, desires a situation as Governess, or to take charge of a small school.
She is competent to teach the higher English branches, together with Latin and French.
Address "J M H," box 527.

Cook, Ironer, Washer and House Servant, for Sale Privately.
A young, Woman, capable of doing . Cooking, Ironing, Washing, and general House with three children, all robust, healthy, and sprighty may be bought privately, not to leave the city or the adiscent counties.
Apply to

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--A young negro Woman, about 16 years old. She is a very good washer.
Inquire at my residence 29th st., near M. Church Hill.
